Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Bio-inspired Thin and Flat Solar Concentrator

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This EAGER project, supported by the Energy, Power and Adaptive Systems program in ECCS aims to develop a highly novel, bio-inspired, thin and flat solar concentrator (TFSC). This imaging optic is stationary and thus reduces the need for a tracker in solar energy applications. For example, it can be used in utility-scale solar farms or integrated with house-building and household items to bring solar energy conversion closer to everyday life. Since solar tracking is precluded in such stationary applications, the acceptance angle becomes an important issue. To achieve a wide acceptance angle in a TFSC without sacrificing its collection efficiency, ease of fabrication, or compactness, we plan to borrow useful concepts from nature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF EAGER project aims to realize a new polymer-based solar concentrator that can be incorporated into household and house-building items to promote the adoption of solar energy conversion. Thin and flat panel architecture has been regarded as the most ideal form for that purpose but implementing the basic operation, i.e., gathering of sunlight from the broadside and efficient delivery of the collected light to the solar cell-installed edge, into it raised significant technical challenges which cannot be easily overcome with conventional non-imaging optics. In particular, the task of low-loss re-direction of the collected light from vertical to lateral propagation seemed insurmountable. 

Nature offers a good model system. The lens-waveguide paired system in insects' compound eyes, often called an ommatidium, is known to achieve such collection and re-direction smoothly through the use of a gradually curved thin biological waveguide. Its artificial replication can provide an immediate solution to the re-direction requirement. A more interesting aspect is that the ommatidium structure does not have to be replicated unmodified. In fact, it turned out that simplifying the inherently 3D ommatidium into a 2D-extruded membrane form can provide a better configuration to cope with the daily solar path and its seasonal changes.

For proactive exploitation of the ommatidium-originated biological inspiration, we organized our efforts in two major thrusts. First, we tried to develop polymer processing techniques which will enable facile fabrication of the thin polymeric waveguide, either in the 3D cylindrical form or the 2D extruded membrane form. Secondly, we tried to increase our understanding of the ommatidium structure itself. The main target was the mysterious ommatidium structure of the butterfly's afocal apposition eye which seemingly defies the fundamental principle of optics. It has been intriguing biologists for decades. The project accrued its intellectual merit by establishing solutions to these issues. 

Through our effort for process development, we made a significant breakthrough in the field of unconventional microsystems. Using PDMS, an elastomer generally deemed too soft to form any type of high-aspect ratio vertical structure, we demonstrated upright micropillars with their height and aspect-ratio exceeding 2 mm and 100, respectively.  Moreover, as shown in Fig. 1, our method allows an automatic attachment of a microsphere at the top of the micropillar, enabling self-aligned integration of microlens, or other functional microbeads, at no extra effort. These unprecedented outcomes have been praised and cited by many for their potentially beneficial impact on a wide range of research fields, including nano/microsystems and biotechnology. 

On the ommatidium analysis side, we also made a breakthrough by finding one possible interpretation to the previously unexplainable optical structure of the butterfly eye. The new outcome bases itself on extensive and iterative numerical simulations on the previously verified model of the structure, which add credibility to the interpretation. The newly found optical waveguide mode-transformation mechanism will also be useful in pure optics community as the basis for miniaturized mode transformers.

Both of these main achievements are highly transformative in their inherently cross-disciplinary nature. Both thrusts harmonized biological inspirations, computerized analysis, and pursuit of solutions that will be useful to researchers in other fields.
